title: Memorials of Edinburgh in the olden time
author: Wilson, Daniel
snippet: On entering Dickson's Close, a little farther down the street, the first house the visitor comes to, on the left hand, is a neat and very substantial stone edifice, evidently the work of Robert Mylne, and built about the period of the Revolution. Of its first occupants we can give no account, but one of its more recent inhabitants is calculated to give it a peculiar interest.

title: Memorials of Edinburgh in the olden time
author: Wilson, Daniel
snippet: the lively expression and spirit of the " General Assembly," and others of his own etchings, amply justify the character he enjoyed among his contemporaries as a truthful and humorous delineator of nature. He succeeded Runciman as master of the Academy established by the Board of Trustees, the classes of which then met in the College, while he received private pupds at his own house in Dickson's Close.1 A little lower down the close on the same side, an old and curious stone tenement bears on its lower crowstep the Haliburton Arms, impaled with another coat, on one shield. It is a singularly unique and time-worn edifice, evidently of considerable antiquity.

title: Memorials of Edinburgh in the olden time
author: Wilson, Daniel
snippet: final residence was in Dickson's Close.
